definitions.definition: A formalized choice on legally relevant measures such as employment or appointment to office or a proceeding about a legal dispute .
examples: The city council decided the matter should go to public vote .
Parliament will hold a vote of confidence regarding the minister.
One occasion indicative votes were used was in 2003 when MPs were presented with seven different options on how to reform the House of Lords.

definitions.definition: An act or instance of participating in such a choice, e.g., by submitting a ballot .
examples: The Supreme Court upheld the principle of one person, one vote .

definitions.definition: an ardent wish or desire ; a vow ; a prayer
any judgment of intellect leading to a formal opinion , a point of view
any judgment of intellect leading not only to a formal opinion but also to a particular choice in a legally relevant measure, a point of view as published
examples: dissenting vote (i.e. in particular the differing opinion published with a judicial judgment considered as a source of information)

main_definition: A formalized choice on legally relevant measures such as employment or appointment to office or a proceeding about a legal dispute .
secondary_definitions: An act or instance of participating in such a choice, e.g., by submitting a ballot .
( obsolete ) an ardent wish or desire ; a vow ; a prayer
( obsolete ) a formalized petition or request
( obsolete ) any judgment of intellect leading to a formal opinion , a point of view
any judgment of intellect leading not only to a formal opinion but also to a particular choice in a legally relevant measure, a point of view as published
